revision.text:
[[File:Fred Merkle 1908.jpg|thumb|right|Fred Merkle, 1908]] '''Merkle's Boner''' refers to the notorious [[baserunning|base-running]] mistake committed by rookie [[Fred Merkle]] of the [[History of the New York Giants (baseball)|New York Giants]] in a game against the [[Chicago Cubs]] on September 23, 1908. Merkle's failure to advance to second base on what should have been a game-winning hit led instead to a forceout at second and a tied game. The Cubs later won the makeup game, which proved decisive as they beat the Giants by one game to win the [[National League]] (NL) [[Pennant (sports)|pennant]] for [[1908 Major League Baseball season|1908]]. It has been described as "the most controversial game in baseball history".<ref>Murphy, p. 421</ref> == Background == The NL pennant race of 1908 was a three-team fight among the teams that dominated the league in the first decade of the modern era: the Pittsburgh (then often spelled Pittsburg) [[Pittsburgh Pirates|Pirates]] (pennant winners in 1901, 1902, and 1903), the Giants (winners in 1904 and 1905), and the Cubs (winners in 1906 and 1907).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/|title=National League Team Win Totals – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> The teams were clustered in the standings all year, with Pittsburgh never more than 2.5 games up or 5 back,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/PIT/1908-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1908 Pittsburgh Pirates Schedule and Results – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> the Giants never more than 4.5 up or 6.5 back,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYG/1908-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1908 New York Giants Schedule and Results – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> and the Cubs never more than 4 games up or 6 games back.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHC/1908-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1908 Chicago Cubs Schedule and Results – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> When play began at the [[Polo Grounds]] in New York City on September 23, 1908, the Cubs and Giants were tied for first place (although the Giants had six more games to play, with an 87–50 record as opposed to the Cubs' 90–53), and the Pirates were 1.5 games back with an 88–54 record.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/games/standings.cgi?date=1908-09-22|title=Standings on Tuesday, September 22, 1908 – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref>
Merkle was 19 years old in 1908, the youngest player in the National League.<ref>{{cite book|last=Vaccaro|first=Mike|title=The First Fall Classic|year=2009|publisher=Doubleday|edition=[[E-book]]|ISBN=978-0-385-53218-1|page=232|authorlink=Mike Vaccaro}}</ref> He played in only 38 games all year,<ref name=giantsstats>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYG/1908.shtml|title=1908 New York Giants Batting, Pitching, & Fielding Statistics – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> 11 of which were at first base as the backup for regular Giants first baseman [[Fred Tenney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYG/1908-fielding.shtml|title=1908 New York Giants Fielding Statistics – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> Merkle was recovering from two foot surgeries in July following a blood infection that nearly caused his foot to be amputated and was unable to play for most of July and August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Baseball Notes|work=Lowell Sun|issue=p. 22|date=July 16, 1908}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Fred Merkle Badly Hurt|work=Newark Advocate|issue=p. 3|date=July 10, 1908}}</ref> On the morning of September 23, Tenney woke up with a case of [[lumbago]], and Giants manager [[John McGraw]] penciled Merkle in at first base. It was the first big-league game Merkle had ever started.<ref>Murphy, p. 431</ref>
== Game == {{Linescore| | Date = September 23, 1908 | Time = | Location = [[Polo Grounds]], [[New York City]], New York |Road=Chicago Cubs|RoadAbr=CHC |R1=0|R2=0|R3=0|R4=1|R5=0|R6=0|R7=0|R8=0|R9=0|RR=1|RH=5|RE=3 |Home=New York Giants|HomeAbr=NYG |H1=0|H2=0|H3=0|H4=0|H5=1|H6=0|H7=0|H8=0|H9=0|HR=1|HH=6|HE=0 |RoadHR= [[Joe Tinker]] |HomeHR= | Attendance = 20,000 (Time: 1:30) |}} Future Hall-of-Famer [[Christy Mathewson]] started for the Giants; [[Jack Pfiester]] started for the Cubs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/boxscore/09231908.shtml|title=Baseball Almanac – Box Score of Merkle's Boner|work=baseball-almanac.com}}</ref> As was customary at the time, the game had only two umpires: [[Bob Emslie]] on the basepaths and [[Hank O'Day]] behind the plate.<ref>Murphy, pp. 425–6</ref>
The Giants were the home team. Neither Mathewson nor Pfiester allowed a run through three innings. In the fourth, Cubs shortstop [[Joe Tinker]] hit the ball into the outfield, and when right fielder [[Mike Donlin]] could not stop it from going past him deep into the cavernous outfield of the Polo Grounds, Tinker circled the bases for an inside-the-park home run that gave Chicago a 1–0 lead. It was the first homer hit off Mathewson since a homer by Tinker on July 17.<ref>Murphy, p. 433</ref> The Giants tied the score in the fifth when [[Buck Herzog]] singled, advanced to second on an [[error (baseball)|error]], advanced to third on a [[Sacrifice bunt|sacrifice]] by [[Roger Bresnahan]], and scored on a single by Donlin. The game was still tied 1–1 when the Giants came to bat in the bottom of the ninth.<ref>Murphy, p. 434</ref>
== The incident == Pfiester remained on the mound for Chicago. [[Cy Seymour]] led off with a groundout to second. [[Art Devlin (baseball)|Art Devlin]] singled, putting the winning run on first base with one out. [[Moose McCormick]] grounded sharply to second, but Devlin's aggressive slide prevented a [[double play]] and allowed McCormick to reach first base safely on a [[fielder's choice]].<ref>Murphy, p. 435</ref> With two outs and McCormick on first, Fred Merkle came up to bat. Merkle, who only had 47 plate appearances in the entire 1908 season,<ref name=giantsstats /> singled down the right-field line. McCormick, the potential winning run, advanced to third base.<ref>Murphy, p. 437</ref>
[[File:Merkles Boner game Polo Grounds Sept23 1908.jpg|thumb|left|An estimated 40,000 fans watched the game.]] Shortstop [[Al Bridwell]] came up to bat next with two outs and runners at the corners. Bridwell swung at the first pitch from Pfiester, a fastball, and drilled an apparent single into center field. McCormick ran home from third, and the game appeared to be over, a 2–1 Giants victory. Giants fans poured out of the stands and mobbed the field; fans sitting behind home plate customarily crossed the field to exit the ballpark via the outfield in this [[dead ball era|era]]. Merkle, advancing from first base, saw the fans swarming onto the playing field. He turned back to the dugout without ever touching second.<ref>Murphy, p. 439</ref> Official rule 4.09 states that "A run is not scored if the runner advances to home base during a play in which the third out is made ... by any runner being forced out".<ref>[http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/downloads/y2008/official_rules/04_starting_ending_game.pdf MLB Official Rules, Section 4]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/2008/sep/22/sports/chi-080922-chicago-cubs-merkles-boner|title=100-year Anniversary of 'Merkle's Boner'|date=September 23, 2008|first=Ed|last=Sherman|work=Chicago Tribune|page=5|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref><ref>Murphy, p. 446</ref>
Cubs second baseman [[Johnny Evers]] saw an opportunity to have the rule enforced. He shouted to center fielder [[Solly Hofman]], who, though the field was filled with fans, retrieved the ball and threw it to Evers. According to one account, [[Joe McGinnity]], a Giants pitcher who was coaching first base that day, intercepted the ball and threw it away into the crowd of fans. Evers apparently retrieved the ball and touched second base, although some reports stated that he substituted a different ball. Umpires Emslie and O'Day hurriedly consulted and O'Day, who saw the play from home plate, ruled that Merkle had not touched second base, and on that basis Emslie ruled him out on a force, and O'Day ruled that the run did not score.<ref>Murphy, pp. 439–441</ref>
Newspapers told different stories of who had gotten the ball to Evers and how. Christy Mathewson, however, who was coaching first base for the Giants, acknowledged in an affidavit that Merkle never made it to second.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Player-Mathewson-Baseball-American/dp/1568582684#reader_1568582684|title=The Player: Christy Mathewson|first=Philip|last=Seib|page=51}}</ref> One newspaper claimed that Cub players physically restrained Merkle from advancing to second. Retelling the story in 1944, Evers insisted that after McGinnity (who was not playing in the game) had thrown the ball away, Cubs pitcher [[Rube Kroh]] (who also was not in the game) retrieved it from a fan and threw it to shortstop Tinker, who threw it to Evers. (By rule, after a fan or a player who was not in the game touched the ball, it should have been ruled dead.) A contemporary account from the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' supports this version.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sabr.org/cmsFiles/Files/theinsidegame-volume8no4.pdf|title=Scoring the Merkle Play|first=Norman|last=Macht|journal=The Inside Game|volume=8|number=4|page=6}}</ref> However, eight years prior to that, Evers claimed to have gotten the ball directly from Hofman. Five years after the play, Merkle admitted that he had left the field without touching second, but only after umpire Emslie assured them that they had won the game. In 1914, O'Day said that Evers' tag was irrelevant: he had called the third out after McGinnity interfered with the throw from center field.<ref>Murphy, pp. 442–444</ref> Future Hall of Fame umpire [[Bill Klem]] said Merkle's boner was "the rottenest decision in the history of baseball"; Klem believed that the force rule was meant to apply to infield hits, not balls hit to the outfield.<ref>Murphy, p. 447</ref>
== Replayed game == Unable to quickly clear the field of fans, O'Day ruled the game over on account of darkness.<ref>Murphy, p. 450</ref> The game ended a 1–1 tie. National League president [[Harry Pulliam]] upheld the ruling. On October 2, Pulliam rejected the Giants' appeal of O'Day's ruling and the Cubs' call for a forfeit victory and again upheld the umpires, declaring the force play on Merkle valid and the game a tie.<ref>Murphy, p. 561</ref> The Cubs-Giants-Pirates pennant race continued to the final days. The Giants were forced to end the season by playing 10 games in a week due to rainouts.<ref>Murphy, p. 543</ref> After Merkle's boner, the Giants won 10 of their last 15 games to finish 98–55. The Cubs won eight of their last 10 after the Merkle game to also finish 98–55. The Pirates, who beat the Dodgers 2–1 on September 23 to gain a half game on their rivals, won nine of their last 10 to force a makeup game with the Cubs on October 4. The Cubs beat the Pirates 5–2, leaving themselves tied with the Giants, and with the Pirates a half-game back of both teams at 98–56, they were thus eliminated.
On October 6, the National League board of directors agreed with its umpires and with Hank Pulliam, making a final ruling that Merkle had failed to touch second base and that the force rule was correctly applied.<ref>Murphy, p. 584</ref> This left the Cubs and Giants tied at 98–55 and required a makeup game to decide the NL pennant. To decide the pennant (and a spot in the [[World Series]]), the teams had to replay the tie game on October 8. Mathewson, scheduled to start the game, said, "I'm not fit to pitch today. I'm dog tired."<ref>Murphy, p. 591</ref> The crowd was estimated at 40,000, the biggest in baseball history at that time.<ref>Murphy, p. 601</ref> Pfiester pitched for the Cubs again in the rematch,<ref>Murphy, p. 608</ref> but was removed from the game in the first inning after hitting Tenney, walking Herzog (who was promptly picked off), giving up an RBI double to Donlin, and walking Seymour. Future Hall of Famer [[Mordecai Brown|Mordecai "Three Finger" Brown]] entered the game in relief and got out of the jam without allowing another run crossing the plate.<ref>Murphy, pp. 609–610</ref> In the Cubs' half of the third inning, Tinker led off with a triple and scored on a single by [[Johnny Kling]]. Evers walked, [[Frank Schulte]] followed with an RBI double to give the Cubs the lead, and Frank Chance followed with a two-run double.<ref>Murphy, 612–614</ref> From there, Chicago cruised to a 4–2 victory, becoming champions of the NL for the third straight year.
== Aftermath == The Cubs went on to win the [[1908 World Series]], beating the [[Detroit Tigers]] four games to one. This was the Cubs' last world championship for more than a century: the next came in the [[2016 World Series]]. The Pirates won the [[1909 World Series]], also against the Tigers. The Giants then returned to the World Series for three straight years, 1911–1913, only to lose each year—to the first of [[Connie Mack]]'s two [[Philadelphia Athletics]] dynasties in {{wsy|1911}} and {{wsy|1913}}, and to the [[Boston Red Sox]] in {{wsy|1912}}. John McGraw's club did not win another championship until {{wsy|1921}}, when they defeated the emerging [[New York Yankees]], featuring [[Babe Ruth]], two consecutive years in the Yankees' first World Series appearances.
''[[The New York Times]]'' game story for September 23, 1908, blamed the loss on "censurable stupidity on the part of player Merkle".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/packages/html/sports/year_in_sports/09.23.html|title=A Boner Buries The Giants|work=New York Times|date=September 23, 1908}}</ref> For the rest of his life, he lived with the nickname of "Bonehead".<ref name=ESPN>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=3604289&type=story|title=Sadly, one play defined Merkle's career|first=Ed|last=Sherman|work=ESPN.com|date=Sep 23, 2008}}</ref> Merkle replaced Tenney as the full-time Giants first baseman in 1910 and was a regular for the Giants, Dodgers, and Cubs for another 10 years. He played in five World Series, all for the losing team.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/merklfr01.shtml|title=Fred Merkle Statistics and History – Baseball-Reference.com|work=baseball-reference.com}}</ref> Bitter over the events of the Merkle's boner game, Merkle avoided baseball after his playing career finally ended in 1926. When he finally appeared at a Giants old-timers' game in 1950, he got a loud ovation from the fans.<ref name=ESPN />
Merkle's Bar and Grill, a popular [[Wrigleyville]] bar just one block south of [[Wrigley Field]] in Chicago, is named after Fred Merkle, and features his image prominently in the bar's logo and interior. The bar's website recounts the story of Merkle's infamous baserunning gaffe, and its e-mail list is titled "The Bonehead".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merkleschicago.com/|title=Merkles Bar and Grill – The Pink Flamingo !|work=merkleschicago.com}}</ref>
On July 1, 2013, a [[Minor League Baseball|minor league]] game between the [[Lansing Lugnuts]] and [[Great Lakes Loons]] featured a very similar play, in which an apparent game-winning single for the Lugnuts was nullified when the runner at first joined the celebration instead of advancing to second.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Fr8mjRo544&t=1m0s |title=Lansing Lugnuts Great Lakes Loons 7/1/13 Grabbing Defeat Out of the Hands of Victory |accessdate=November 14, 2018 |via=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> The Lugnuts lost in extra innings.<ref>[http://deadspin.com/minor-leaguer-hits-walk-off-single-his-team-loses-game-656822487 Minor Leaguer Hits Walk-Off Single, His Team Loses Game], Tom Ley, Deadspin</ref><ref>[http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130702&content_id=52434360&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_milb&tcid=tw_share Loons Win in Merkle-esque Fashion], Jake Seiner, MiLB.com</ref>

[[SIU Edwardsville Cougars#Cross country and track and field|SIUE men's & women's track & field]] | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''Ralph Korte Stadium''', also known as "The Ralph", is a 4,000 seat [[stadium]] located on the campus of [[Southern Illinois University Edwardsville]] in [[Edwardsville, Illinois|Edwardsville]], [[Illinois]]. It is home to the SIUE [[SIU Edwardsville Cougars|Cougars]] men's and women's [[soccer]] and outdoor [[track & field]] teams.{{cite web |url=https://www.enjoyillinois.com/en-us/thingstodo/details/30871 |title=Southern Illinois University Edwardsville Ralph Korte Stadium & Sports Complex |work=Travel Illinois |publisher=ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY |accessdate=20 January 2012 }} In addition to the stands on the west side of the field, a berm was put in on the east side in 2011 to provide lawn seating for the [[Tailgate party|tailgating fans]] known as "The East Siders." The stadium was constructed on university property surrounding the existing "Bob Guelker Field" in 1993–94 by the City of Edwardsville as a site to host the 1994 [[U.S. Olympic Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.siue.edu/lovejoylibrary/archives/timeline.shtml |title=SIUE 50th Anniversary Historical Timeline |publisher=Southern Illinois University Edwardsville |accessdate=20 January 2012 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.siue.edu/maps/tour/korte.shtml |title=Maps & Directions - Ralph Korte Stadium|publisher=Southern Illinois University Edwardsville |accessdate=20 January 2012 }} In 1998, the university trustees named the stadium to honor Ralph Korte, the founder of [[The Korte Company]] of [[Highland, Illinois|Highland]], an SIUE alumnus and strong advocate of the school.{{cite web |url=http://www.siue.edu/alumni/profiles/profile-korte.shtml |title=Alumni Profiles- Ralph Korte |website=Southern Illinois University Edwardsville |publisher=Southern Illinois University Edwardsville |accessdate=1 September 2016 }} The soccer playing surface was named, on November 1, 1986, in honor of [[Bob Guelker]], the coach who inaugurated SIUE's men's soccer program and led it to the [[NCAA]] [[NCAA Division II Men's Soccer Championship|Division II]] championship in 1972 and the [[NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship|Division I]] crown in 1979. The Korte Stadium and its earlier incarnation, Cougar Field, has hosted the [[NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship]] in 1970 and 1975, the 1972 [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] [[NCAA Division II Men's Soccer Championship|Men's Soccer Championship]], and the Division II [[NCAA Men's Outdoor Track and Field Championship]] in 1997, 1998, 2001, and 2003. It was also the home stadium for the [[Saint Louis Athletica]] of [[Women's Professional Soccer]] for part of their 2009 season, during which the capacity was expanded to 5,000 seats; the team later started playing at [[World Wide Technology Soccer Park|Anheuser-Busch Soccer Park]]. The track features eight 48-inch lanes, with European-style broad turns (118 meters) and short straightaways (82 meters). The field event facilities include high jump aprons; pole vault runways; long jump/triple jump pits; shot put, discus, and hammer throw rings; and javelin throw runways on the west side, just outside the stadium grandstand. The [[Gateway Arch]] on the [[St. Louis]] riverfront, 25 miles to the southwest, can be seen from the top of the stands at The Ralph. The record single-day attendance for a track & field competition is 11,072 on July 10, 1994 at the U.S. Olympic Festival. Although an estimated crowd of over 8,000 was present for the 1971 Bronze Boot game versus [[Saint Louis Billikens men's soccer|St. Louis]] at Cougar Field, the largest soccer crowd in the stadium's current configuration was 4,665 for the Homecoming game against [[Bradley Braves men's soccer|Bradley]] on October 4, 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.siuecougars.com/sports/m-soccer/2014-15/boxscores/20141004_xj9b.xml |title=Bradley vs. SIUE at Edwardsville, Ill., 10/4/2014 at 7 p.m. |publisher=Southern Illinois University Edwardsville |date=4 October 2014 |accessdate=5 October 2014 }} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.siue.edu Official SIUE website] * [http://www.siue.edu/maps/tour/vc.shtml Venue information (Map and photos)] * [http://www.siuecougars.com/facilities/ralph_korte_stadium.html Cougars facilities (Ralph Korte Stadium)] {{S-start}} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship|College Cup]] | years = 1970
1975 | before = [[Spartan Stadium (San Jose)|Spartan Stadium]]
[[Busch Memorial Stadium]] | after = [[Miami Orange Bowl]]
[[Franklin Field]] }} {{End}} {{Coord|38.782458|-90.011394|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Southern Illinois University Edwardsville campus}} [[Category:Edwardsville, Illinois]] [[Category:Southern Illinois University Edwardsville]] [[Category:Saint Louis Athletica]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Illinois]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:College track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Illinois]]

Gwaltney, Jr. | industry = [[Sports equipment]] | products = [[Clothing]], [[Sneakers|Athletic shoes]], [[Sports equipment]], [[Fashion accessory|Accessories]] | revenue = [[United States dollar|US$]]1.438 billion[http://www.manta.com/c/mmcmp5h/russell-corp Russell Corp. profile in Manta.com website] | num_employees = 10,000 | parent = [[Fruit of the Loom]][https://www.russellathletic.com/pages/about About] on Russell Athletic website, retrieved 12 Jan 2017
([[Berkshire Hathaway]]) | divisions = | subsid = [[Russell Athletic (brand)|Russell Athletic]], [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] | homepage = {{URL|www.russell-brands.com}} }} '''Russell Brands, LLC''', headquartered in [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]], is an American manufacturer of [[sports equipment]], which markets its products under many brands and subsidiaries, including [[Russell Athletic (brand)|Russell Athletic]] (its flagship brand) and [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]]. Formerly a [[publicly traded]] company, Russell Brands has been a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Berkshire Hathaway]] since 2006. ==History== === The beginning: Russell Manufacturing Co. === {{Main article|Russell Athletic (brand)}} === Russell Corp. established === The original "Russell Manufacturing Company", founded by Benjamin Russell in [[Alexander City, Alabama]], in 1902,[http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/48/Russell-Corporation.html Russell Corporation history in "Reference for Business" website] became "Russell Corporation" in 1973, under the presidency of Eugene C. Gwaltney, Jr., who had taken over in 1968. By 1990, the company owned and operated 13 sewing plants outside Alexander City and employed 15,000 workers. Since 1976, sales revenues had increased by 13 percent annually. With the acquisition of two subsidiaries, Quality Mills in North Carolina and Cloathbond Ltd. in Scotland, in 1988 and 1989 respectively, the company had become a global contender in the sportswear industry. Under president and [[CEO]] John C. Adams, Russell Corporation had become the top manufacturer of athletic uniforms in the US. In 1992, the company was awarded a five-year contract to be the exclusive producer and marketer of athletic uniforms for most [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] teams. The contract also stipulated that the company held the exclusive right to manufacture and market replicas of major league uniforms, T-shirts and shorts. This put the company in an advantageous position in relation to its main rival, [[Champion (sportswear)|Champion, Inc.]], the supplier of uniforms to the [[NBA]] teams. In 1992 alone, Russell's international sales increased by 40 percent over 1991. === Major restructuring === Although sales and net income reached record levels in 1996, in part because of the impact of the [[Summer Olympics]] which were held in [[Atlanta]] that year, Russell's fortunes turned down in 1997 when both sales and net income fell. The decline was caused by intensifying competition as industry-wide over-capacity and price-cutting by rivals forced Russell to lower its own prices, all of which hurt the company's results. Particularly troubled was the Licensed Products Division, which Russell dissolved in 1997, dividing its operations among the other divisions. In 1997, Russell also ended its licensing deals with the professional football, basketball and hockey leagues. In early 1998, as the company's troubles continued, Adams retired. John "Jack" Ward stepped in as chairman, president and CEO. Within months of his arrival, Russell announced a major restructuring. Over a three-year period, the company planned to eliminate about 4,000 jobs, or 23 percent of its workforce; close about 25 of its 90 plants, distribution centers and other facilities; and move most of the final assembly of garments abroad, to [[Mexico]], [[Honduras]] and elsewhere in the Caribbean basin. The company expected to take charges of $100 to $125 million during the restructuring period. Russell hoped these efforts would result in annual savings of $50–$70 million. Part of these funds would then be used to bolster the marketing and advertising of Russell's brands, including tripling the advertising budget to $25 million per year. Russell also established a second headquarters in Atlanta in February 1999. Restructuring charges led Russell to post a net loss for fiscal year 1998 of $10.4 million on revenues of $1.18 billion. Results for the first half of 1999 also showed a net loss of $12.9 million but the restructuring had resulted in a decrease in selling, general and administration costs of 13 percent. Russell had also increased its offshore apparel assembly to 55 percent of total capacity, a substantial increase from the 17 percent level before the restructuring was launched. Russell had far to go before it could be considered fully turned around, but it appeared that the company was well on its way. The company completed its restructuring process in 2001. Nearly all of its retail outlets had been closed, over 6,000 jobs had been cut, and most of its manufacturing operations had moved abroad. In 2000, Russell Corp. acquired the apparel operations for Haas Outdoors, Inc.. This later became the [[Mossy Oak]] Apparel Company.http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/48/Russell-Corporation.html In 2002, the company added the [[Bike Athletic Company]] and [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] to its holding. Russell continued its acquisition spree in 2004 by purchasing American Athletic Inc. (AAI), [[Huffy|Huffy Corp.]]'s sports division and [[Brooks Sports]]. It also secured an extended contract to provide Spalding and Huffy branded products to the National Basketball Association. The company faced challenges in 2005 due to rising costs and falling sales. During Hurricanes Rita and Katrina, over 40 containers of Russell products were lost or destroyed and nearly 70 percent of the ports it used for shipping were closed. Amid intense competition and faltering profits, the company launched a restructuring plan much like the effort of the late 1990s. Russell continued shifting its manufacturing base overseas and cut a total of 2,300 jobs. Conglomerate [[Berkshire Hathaway|Berkshire Hathaway Inc]]. acquired Russell Corporation for $600 million in early 2006. Berkshire, led by the billionaire [[Warren Buffett]], believed Russell would be a good fit with its [[Fruit of the Loom|Fruit of the Loom Inc]]. subsidiary. ==Brands== The Russell Corporation is made up of the following brands and their products:[http://www.russell-brands.com/ Brands of the Russell Corporation] ===Current brands=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width="360px" |- ! width=100px| Brand ! width=200px| Products ! width=60px| Year added |- |align=center| [[Russell Athletic (brand)|Russell Athletic]] || [[Clothing]] (uniforms for college and school teams) || Former company |- |align=center| [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] || [[Ball]]s, accessories || 2003 [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9505E4D6173AF93BA25757C0A9659C8B63 Russell is buying most of Spalding Sporting Goods unit], New York Times, 2003-04-18 |- |align=center| Jerzees || [[T-shirt]]s || 1992 |} ===Former brands=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width="360px" |- ! width=100px| Brand ! width=200px| Products ! width=60px| Year added |- |align=center| [[BIKE Athletic Company|Bike]] || Protections || 2002 |- |align=center| [[Brooks Sports|Brooks]] || [[Athletic shoe]]s, clothing || 2004 |- |align=center| Dudley || [[Softball]] balls and accessories || 2003 |- |align=center| American Athletic || [[Gymnastics]]' tables, bars, rings, [[Vault (gymnastics)|horses]] || 2004 |} ==Honduran labor controversy and boycott== [[File:StudentsMarchOnRussellHQ.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Members of United Students Against Sweatshops march outside of Russell Corporation's offices in Atlanta, GA.]] Since January 2009, Russell faced the largest collegiate [[boycott]] of an apparel company in history over labor violations in its Honduran factories.[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/24/business/24sweat.html?_r=2&ref=business "Michigan Is the Latest University to End a Licensing Deal With an Apparel Maker"], New York Times, February 23, 2009 (retrieved July 30, 2009).Bonior, David (February 13, 2009). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-bonior/schools-score-points-by-s_b_166823.html "Schools Score Points by Standing Up for Workers"], ''[[Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved on July 30, 2009.[http://media.wildcat.arizona.edu/media/storage/paper997/news/2009/07/22/News/Labor.Pains-3752569.shtml "Labor pains: UA ends contract with Russell Athletics after labor report alleges abuses], ''Daily Wildcat'', July 22, 2009 (retrieved July 31, 2009).[http://digital.lib.washington.edu/findingaids/view?docId=BrandResponsiblityProject5683.xml Brand Responsibility Project Records.] 2004-2012. 0.84 cubic feet (2 boxes) of textual materials plus 83.8 GB of digital files. The boycott was co-ordinated by United Students Against Sweatshops in the United States and Canada in support of the Honduran garment workers' union SITRAJERZEESH.Dreier, Peter (June 14, 2009). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/peter-dreier/human-rights-activists-pr_b_215326.html "Human Rights Activists Protest NBA-Linked Sweatshops"]. ''Huffington Post''. Retrieved July 30, 2009.[http://usas.org "Congressional Letter, New Video, & 70 universities boycott Warren Buffett's Russell Athletic!"]. United Students Against Sweatshops. Retrieved July 31, 2009. The [[Worker Rights Consortium]] has documented violations of the rights of workers by Russell in its factory Jerzees de Honduras. The report found that Russell illegally fired nearly 2,000 in two of its factories, in retaliation for employees protesting against working conditions and forming a union. The report also stated that death threats were allegedly made against some members of the union, though not by senior management.{{citation | title = Russell Corporation's Rights Violations Threaten 1,800 Jobs in Honduras | publisher = Workers Rights Consortium | date = November 7, 2008 | url = http://workersrights.org/RussellRightsViolations.asp | accessdate = February 13, 2009 }} In response, over eighty universities have canceled their contracts with Russell, including [[Duke University]], [[Georgetown University]], [[Columbia University]], [[University of Michigan]], [[University of Miami]], [[University of Maryland]], [[University of Washington]], [[University of Houston]], [[Penn State University]], [[Rutgers University]], [[University of Minnesota-Twin Cities]], [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], [[Purdue University]], [[Cornell University]], [[University of Florida]], and the [[University of Aberdeen]] in Scotland.{{citation | title = Schools Score Points by Standing Up for Workers | publisher = Huffington Post | date = February 13, 2009 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-bonior/schools-score-points-by-s_b_166823.html | accessdate = February 13, 2009 }} {{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/2009-02-24-michigan-russell-liscensing_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Michigan joins list of schools scrapping deals with Russell | date=February 25, 2009 | accessdate=May 23, 2010}}[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/02/25/Univ_of_Wash_drops_Russell_logo_license/UPI-19331235592173/ "Univ. of Wash. drops Russell logo license", 25 February 2009][http://www.tampabay.com/news/education/college/university-of-florida-cuts-sportswear-ties-with-russell-athletic/1007472 "University of Florida cuts sportswear ties with Russell", ''Tampa Bay Times''] On May 13, 2009, sixty-five [[United States House of Representatives|members of Congress]] wrote to Russell CEO John Holland to express their concern over the labor violations.[http://hare.house.gov/uploads/Russell%20Letter.pdf "Letter from Congressmembers to Russell"]. Retrieved July 31, 2009. On June 25, 2009, Russell became the first collegiate licensee to be placed on [[probation]] by the [[Fair Labor Association]].[http://www.fairlabor.org/images/NewsandPublications/NewsReleasesandStatements2009/board_resolution_russell_jun.25.09.pdf "FLA Board Resolution"], Fair Labor Association, June 25, 2009 (retrieved July 31, 2009). At first, Russell said it was being unfairly targeted by the garment workers' union and student activists, and that the plant closure was due to the general downturn in the world economy.http://www.dailycardinal.com/article/22040 Five schools announced they planned to continue doing business with Russell.[http://www.ajc.com/services/content/printedition/2009/02/28/techrussell0228.html ]http://www.wbko.com/news/headlines/40305312.html However, at least one of those, the [[University of Florida]], has since terminated its licensing deal with Russell.[http://www.tampabay.com/news/education/college/article1007472.ece "University of Florida cuts sportswear ties with Russell Athletic"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608052000/http://www.tampabay.com/news/education/college/article1007472.ece |date=2009-06-08 }}, ''St. Petersburg Times'', June 5, 2009 (retrieved July 31, 2009).[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090530/ARTICLES/905301014/1105/NEWS?Title=UF-terminates-licensing-agreement-with-Russell-Athletic "UF terminates licensing agreement with Russell Athletic Officials with UF and Russell would not make additional comments."], ''Gainesville Sun'', May 29, 2009 (retrieved July 31, 2009). The company had issued a statement noting that it had recognized the unionization of the Jerzees de Honduras plant on October 3, 2007. In later statements, the company admitted wrongdoing, although the violations are yet to be resolved.,[http://www.russellsocialresponsibility.com "Russell Athletic open letter"], July 15, 2009 (retrieved July 31, 2009). ==Sponsorships== Throughout its history, Russell Corporation has been involved in the manufacturing and selling of equipment for many professional, collegiate and high school sports teams. Most notable of these are its stint of manufacturing uniforms for [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] (through its flagship brand, [[Russell Athletic (brand)|Russell Athletic]]), the production of official basketballs for the [[NBA]] (through its subsidiary [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]]), and the production of official footballs for the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] (under the [[Sherrin]] Brand). ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120023316/http://www.russell-brands.com/index.html Russell Brands LLC] (Archive) *[http://www.fotlinc.com/index.html Fruit of the Loom, Inc.] *[http://www.russellathletic.com Russell Athletic] *[http://www.brooksrunning.com/ Brooks] *[http://www.jerzees.com Jerzees] *[http://www.dudleysports.com/ Dudley Sports] *[http://www.americanathletic.com/ American Athletics (AAI)] *[http://workersrights.org/RussellRightsViolations.asp Report on Russell Corporation labor violations in Honduras] {{Berkshire Hathaway}} [[Category:Companies based in Alexander City, Alabama]] [[Category:Berkshire Hathaway]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1902]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1902]] [[Category:1902 establishments in Alabama]]

[[File:Liverpool footballer Steven Gerrard.jpg|thumb|right|232px|[[Steven Gerrard]] shooting for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].]] [[File:Niclas Jensen shooting FC Copenhagen FC Vestsjælland 05.04.2009.JPG|thumb|240px|right|[[Niclas Jensen]] shoots for goal in a match for [[F.C. Copenhagen]] against [[FC Vestsjælland]].]]
Shooting is easily the most common way for [[Scoring in association football|goals to be scored]]. It is done using the feet; using the head, i.e. heading the ball, is the second most common way in which goals are scored.<ref name="The Soccer Shooting Guide"/>
== Types of shots ==
* [[Instep]] drive: This shot is done with the laces of a boot and is widely used. The ball is struck through with the laces or the top part of the foot. The shot is powerful but less accurate.<ref name="The Soccer Shooting Guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.soccer-training-guide.com/soccer-shooting.html |title=The Soccer Shooting Guide |publisher=Soccer-training-guide.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-22}}</ref> *[[Curl (football)|Swerve shot]]: This shot is made using the side of the foot (or the outside of the foot on occasion) and is usually but not exclusively used in [[Direct free kick|free kick]]s. The ball bends or swerves in such a way that it beats the keeper, the only drawback is that it lacks great power.<ref name="The Soccer Shooting Guide"/> * [[Chip (association football)|Chip]]: Also known as the lob, this shot focuses on getting the ball to a certain amount of vertical height, where the [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] can't reach it and then have it come back down again into goal, it takes a certain amount of technique and precision to do and players such as [[Raúl González]], [[Cristiano Ronaldo]], [[Roberto Baggio]], [[Romário]], [[Francesco Totti]], [[Alessandro Del Piero]] and [[Lionel Messi]] have made it trademark moves.<ref name="The Soccer Shooting Guide"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/international-football/2017/02/22/58adac0ae5fdea9b038b45d2.html|title=The art of the chip: Falcao matches Totti, Messi and Raul|publisher=Marca|author1=Joel del Río|date=22 February 2017|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-italia.net/48791/baggio%E2%80%99s-month-may|title=Baggio’s month of May|publisher=Football Italia|author1=Dave Taylor|date=5 May 2014|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/150issue/delpieroicon.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104150909/http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/150issue/delpieroicon.html|archivedate=4 January 2009|title=Calcio Italia 150 issue, Calcio Icons, Del Piero|publisher=Channel4.com|last=Gilbert|first=Dan|date=22 July 2009|accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Knuckleball]]: A freekick or shot from distance that has no spin and has erratic movement, [[Juninho Pernambucano]], [[Andrea Pirlo]], [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] and [[Gareth Bale]] are known for using this technique.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2279588/Gareth-Bales-secret-free-kick-method-revealed.html | title=The secret behind Bale's free-kick prowess that can be traced back to baseball a century ago | publisher=Daily Mail | date=16 February 2013 | accessdate=22 October 2013 | author=Shergold, Adam}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Juventus: Pirlo, ma che punizione hai tirato? La maledetta che sfida la fisica|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Squadre/Juventus/11-11-2013/juventus-pirlo-ma-che-punizione-hai-tirato-maledetta-che-sfida-fisica-201549826321.shtml|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref> * [[Toe punt]]: Used with less frequency, and also known as the "toe poke", this shot uses the toe of the [[Football boot|boot]]; as it is a quick strike which requires little motion, it is often utilized to fool or surprise opponents who would normally not expect this type of shot, such as when [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] used it to score [[Brazil national football team|Brazil's]] decisive goal in the semi-final of the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 World Cup]] against [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]].<ref name="Encounter 1965 85">{{cite journal|author=Congress for Cultural Freedom|journal=Encounter|year=1965|volume=25|pages=85}}</ref><ref name="Hargreaves 1990 153">{{cite book|last=Hargreaves|first=Alan|title=Skills and strategies for coaching soccer|year=1990|publisher=Leisure Press|location=Champaign, Ill.|isbn=0880113286|pages=153}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2015/m=3/news=in-praise-of-the-toe-poke-2555654.html|title=In praise of the toe-poke|website=www.fifa.com|publisher=FIFA|date=6 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goalden.com/2010/04/i-thought-the-toe-punt-was-a-bad-thing/|title=I thought the toe-punt was a bad thing?|website=www.goalden.com|author1=Ivan Bobanovic|date=23 April 2010|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Gear full.sized.png|thumb|200px|[[Rock-climbing equipment]]: Rope and climber's shoes]]'''Sporting equipment''', also called sporting goods, has various forms depending on the sport, but it is essential to complete the sport. The equipment ranges from balls, to nets, and to [[protective gear]] like helmets. Sporting equipment can be used as protective gear or as tool used to help the athletes play the sport. Over time, sporting equipment has evolved because sports have started to require more protective gear to prevent injuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.medic8.com/healthguide/sports-medicine/prevention/equipment.html|title=Sports Protective Equipment - Sports Injury Prevention|website=www.medic8.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-23}}</ref> Sporting equipment may be found in any department store.
==Game equipment== ===Balls=== {{see also|Category:Balls}} The [[ball]] is often what a sport requires and revolves around. A sports ball is typically round, but can also be in the shape of a [[prolate spheroid]] in the case of an [[Ball (gridiron football)|American football]] or a [[rugby ball]].
Sports are often named after the ball used, such as [[Association football|football]], [[American football]], [[baseball]] and [[basketball]], or the ball is named after the sport.
===Flying discs=== [[Flying disc|Flying discs are used for variou]]s [[Flying disc games|games]] such as [[Flying disc freestyle|freestyle]], [[disc golf]] and [[ultimate (sport)|ultimate]].
===Goal posts=== In many games, [[Goal posts (sport)|goal posts]] are at each end of the playing field, there are two vertical posts (or uprights) supporting a horizontal crossbar. In some games, such as [[association football|football]] or [[hockey]], the object is to pass the ball or puck between the posts below the crossbar, while in others, such as those based on [[Rugby football|rugby]], the ball must pass over the crossbar instead.
===Nets=== [[Net (device)|Nets are used for]] [[tennis]], [[volleyball]], football, basketball, hockey and [[badminton]]. A different type of net is used for various forms of [[fishing]].
===Racquets=== [[Racquet|Racquets are used for]] [[racquet sport]]s such as [[tennis]], [[Squash (sport)|squash]] and [[badminton]].
===Rods and tackle=== [[Fishing rod|Fishing rods and]] [[fishing tackle]] are primarily used for [[fishing]] and [[Recreational fishing|sport fishing]].
===Sticks, bats and clubs=== Sticks are used for sports such as [[hockey]] and [[lacrosse]]. Bats are used for sports such as [[baseball]] and [[cricket]]. Clubs are used mainly for [[golf]] ([[Golf club (equipment)|Golf club]])
===Wickets and bases=== Wickets and balls are used in [[cricket]], and bases are used in [[baseball]].
==Player equipment==
===Footwear=== [[File:Cleats.jpg|thumb|200px|Cleats]]
[[Footwear]] for sports includes: * Boards for [[surfing]], [[skateboarding]], [[wakeboarding]] and [[snowboarding]] * Skates for sports like [[roller skating]] and [[ice skating]] * [[Ski]]s for [[skiing]] and [[water skiing]] * [[Football boot]]s * Cricket spikes * [[Golf shoes]] * [[Track spikes]] * Prosthetics like the [[Cheetah Flex-Foot]] [[The Mechanics of Running Blades|running blade]] * [[Running shoes]] * Walking shoes * Flat pedal shoes and clipless shoes for [[mountain biking]]
===Protective equipment=== Protective equipment is often worn for sports including [[motor sport]] and [[contact sport]]s, such as [[ice hockey]] and [[American football]] or sports where there is a danger of injury through collision of players or other objects. Protective equipment includes: * [[Football helmet]] * [[Jock strap]] * [[Mouthguard]]s * [[Shin pad]]s * [[Ski suit]]s * [[Elbow pad]]s *[[Shoulder pad]]s *[[Bicycle helmet]] *[[:Category:Sports gloves|Sports gloves]]
===Training equipment=== Examples for training equipment include [[exercise ball|swiss ball]]s, [[barbells|weights]], [[chin-up bar]]s, equipment for the [[Health club|gym]]. Also protective equipment such as [[weight lifting belt]]s and [[bench shirt]]s for weight training and [[powerlifting]].
==Miscellaneous==
===Vehicles=== Vehicles (sometimes specialized) are used as equipment for some sports, including [[motor sport]], [[cycling]], [[aeronautics]], [[sailing]] and [[hot air ballooning]].
Small vehicles with [[flatbed truck|flatbeds]] are often used to carry injured athletes off the field, most commonly in [[American football]].
==Various sports== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *[[:Category:Sports equipment]] (various sports) *[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]] *[[Kit (association football)|Association football clothing and equipment]] *[[Baseball clothing and equipment]] *[[Climbing equipment]] *[[Cricket clothing and equipment]] {{col-2}} *[[Golf equipment]] *[[Ice hockey equipment]] *[[Snowboarding equipment]] *[[Triathlon equipment]] {{col-end}}
== History and development of sports == Historically many sports have developed their sporting equipment over time. For instance, the use of a football dates back to ancient China, between 225 BC and 220 AD.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccerballworld.com/History.htm|title=History|website=www.soccerballworld.com|access-date=2016-05-16}}</ref> As football remains the most popular sport in the [[21st century]], the material of the ball has completely changed over the centuries; from being made out of animal skin, to being lined with multiple layers of polyester or cotton.<ref name=":02" />
As the sporting equipment industry improves, so does the athletes performance. This is due to the fact that the equipment is more efficient, lighter and stronger it forming a bio-mechanical system, interacting with the athlete.<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1007/s12283-015-0183-5 | volume=18| issue=4|journal=Sports Engineering|pages=191–202| title=Biomechanics research and sport equipment development| year=2015| last1=Stefanyshyn| first1=Darren J.| last2=Wannop| first2=John W.}}</ref>
Since the massive adoption of wearable, new sport equipment tend to be electronics and connected to deliver data performances.
==See also== *[[Equipment]] *[[Equipment manager]] *[[Outdoor gym]] *[[Protective equipment]] *[[Chin-up bar]]

Cape Verdean National Cup | logo = | caption = | founded = 1982 | region = Cape Verde | number of teams = 11 | current champions = [[Sporting Clube da Praia]] (1st time) | most successful club = [[Boavista FC (Cape Verde)|Boavista Praia]] (2 titles) | broadcasters = [[RTC (Cape Verde)|TCV]] (television)
[[RTC (Cape Verde)|RTC]] (radio) | motto = | website = | current = [[2018 Taça Nacional de Cabo Verde]] }} The '''Taça de Cabo Verde''' (Portuguese for the '''Cape Verdean Cup''', also as the '''Capeverdean Cup''') is the main knock-out football tournament of the [[Cape Verde]] islands. It started in 1982, it was later revived in 2007 and is played annually. The competition features the winners of each island or regional cup competition and competes into two groups. ==History== The first edition took place in 1982 and was only broadcast on radio, television broadcasts did not began until 1997, its first telecast of the cup competition began in 2007. Most of the matches, all of the semis and finals were broadcast on TCV and RCV. Some of the matches were broadcast on regional television and radio including [[Rádio Barlavento]] and [[Rádio Praia]] (or AM Praia). From the 2013 edition, the winner competes in the [[Cape Verdean Cup]], the only time done was [[CD Onze Unidos|Onze Unidos]], the 2012 cup winner. There had been no cup competitions since 2013 and is uncertain about the cancellation of recent tournaments. With the National Championships held in 2017 which originally to finish in July and extended into late-August, the 2017 national cup competition was again not held. It is one of the countries in Africa which a football cup competition was held for just five seasons. The next cup competition is now taking place, for the 2018 season. ==Winners== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Winners ! Score ! Runners-up |- |1982 |'''[[CS Mindelense]]''' |1-0 |[[SC Morabeza|Morabeza]] [Brava]{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kaapv82.html|title=Cape Verde Islands 1982|publisher=RSSSF|date=20 July 2017|accessdate=3 September 2017}} |- |2007 |'''[[Académica da Praia]]''' |3-1 |[[Académico do Aeroporto|Académica do Sal]] |- |2008 |colspan=3|''Bot {{Infobox golf tournament | name = The Bahamas Great Exuma Classic | image = | caption = | location = [[Great Exuma]], [[Bahamas]] | establishment = 2017 | course = Sandals Emerald Bay Golf Course | par = 72 | yardage = {{convert|7000|yd|m}} | org = | tour = [[Web.com Tour]] | format = [[Stroke play]] | purse = [[United States dollar|US$]]600,000 | month_played = January | final_year = | aggregate = 275 [[Im Sung-jae]] (2018) | to-par = −13 ''as above'' | current_champion = {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Im Sung-jae]] | final_champion = }} '''The Bahamas Great Exuma Classic''' is a [[golf]] tournament on the [[Web.com Tour]], played at Sandals Emerald Bay Golf Course in [[the Bahamas]]. It is one of two Web.com Tour events in the Bahamas, along with [[The Bahamas Great Abaco Classic]]. Both events were first played in January 2017 starting on a Sunday and finishing on a Wednesday, rather than the standard Thursday–Sunday schedule.{{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/webcom/news/2016/11/09/new-events-bahamas-great-exuma-classic-great-abaco-classic-wednesday-finish.html |title=2017 season to begin with two Bahamas events, Wednesday finishes |publisher=PGA Tour |date=November 9, 2016}} Due to high winds in the inaugural event, the cut line fell at 11-over-par 155, the highest in Web.com Tour history.{{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/webcom/daily-wrapup/2017/01/10/bahamas-great-exuma-classic-round-3.html |title=Thompson holds lead with 28 holes remaining at The Bahamas Great Exuma Classic |publisher=PGA Tour |date=January 10, 2017 |first=Nick |last=Parker}} The par-4 12th hole played to a stroke average of 5.008, making it the hardest in tour history relative to par.{{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/webcom/daily-wrapup/2017/01/11/kyle-thompson-wins-bahamas-great-exuma-classic.html |title=Thompson emerges victorious at 2017 season opener in Bahamas |publisher=PGA Tour |date=January 11, 2017 |first=Nick |last=Parker}} ==Winners== {|class=wikitable style=font-size:95% !Year!!Winner!!Country!!Score!!To par!!Margin
of victory!!Runners-up |- | [[2018 Web.com Tour|2018]] || '''[[Im Sung-jae]]''' || {{KOR}} || align=center|275 || align=center|−13 || 4 strokes || {{flagicon|MEX}} '''[[Carlos Ortiz (golfer)|Carlos Ortiz]]''' |- | [[2017 Web.com Tour|2017]] || '''[[Kyle Thompson]]''' || {{USA}} || align=center|286 || align=center|−2 || 2 strokes || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Nicholas Thompson (golfer)|Nicholas Thompson]]
{{flagicon|USA}} '''[[Andrew Yun]]''' |} '''Bolded''' golfers graduated to the PGA Tour via the Web.com Tour regular-season money list. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://greatexumaclassic.com}} *[http://www.pgatour.com/webcom/tournaments/the-bahamas-great-exuma-classic.html Coverage on the Web.com Tour's official site] {{Web.com Tour Events}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bahamas Great Exuma Classic}} [[Category:Web.com Tour events]] [[Category:Golf in the Bahamas]] {{Bahamas-sport-stub}} {{golf-tournament-stub}}

{{italic title}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
'''''The Tournament''''', a 2002 [[novel]] in the form of sports-reportage written by New Zealand-born Australian satirist [[John Clarke (satirist)|John Clarke]], depicts a fictional international [[tennis]] tournament held in Paris and featuring a variety of notable twentieth-century literary, cultural and scientific figures as competitors.
Several other identities appear: [[Charles Darwin]] as the tournament referee, for example, and [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] as the "president and CEO of [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]]". [[Oscar Wilde]] and [[James Abbott McNeill Whistler|James McNeill Whistler]] provide commentary. [[Roland Barthes]], [[Emmeline Pankhurst]], [[George Plimpton]], [[Norman Mailer]] and many others appear as sports reporters covering the match. A demonstration doubles match features [[Henrik Ibsen]] and [[Claude Monet]] vs. [[Henry James]] and [[Mark Twain]].
==Coaches== * United States: [[Ernest Hemingway|Ernie Hemingway]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = VCP Chinandega | image = | fullname = Vicente de la Cruz Padilla Chinandega | nickname = ''Los Chinandeganos'' | founded = August, 2006 | dissolved = 2010 | ground = Estadio Efraín Tijerino
[[Chinandega]], [[Nicaragua]] | capacity = 8,000 | chairman = [[Image:Flag of Nicaragua.svg|20px]] [[Vicente Padilla|Vicente de la Cruz Padilla]] | manager = | league = | season = | position = | pattern_la1= |pattern_b1=_bluestriped_sides|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=ffffff|body1=ffffff|rightarm1=ffffff|shorts1=ffffff|socks1=ffffff | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=_white_sleeve_seams|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=0000FF|body2=0000FF|rightarm2=0000FF|shorts2=0000FF|socks2=0000FF| }} '''VCP Chinandega''' was a [[Nicaragua]]n [[Football (soccer)|football]] team who have played 2 years at the country's top level. Located in [[Chinandega]], they were named after [[Vicente Padilla|Vicente de la Cruz Padilla]] (VCP) A baseball player from Chinandega who owned the club.[http://www.elnuevodiario.com.ni/deportes/19994 El sueño de Vicente Padilla con el fútbol “Vamos a competir”] – El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} ==History== The club was founded in August, 2006 by famous baseball player and owner [[Vicente Padilla|Vicente de la Cruz Padilla]]. As a project to promote football to young people in his home town of [[Chinandega]]. With the help of Eddy Reyes, Boanerge Espinoza, Enrique Reyes, Baxter Martínez and Eduardo Vidal Alonso, The club was playing in the [[Nicaraguan Third Division]], predominantly with players from the area. Their rise was unbelievable they won the third division in 2006 and in 2007 won the second division[https://archive.is/20140405221858/http://impreso.elnuevodiario.com.ni/imprimir/2007-08-18/56596 Fut de Segunda inicia el domingo] – El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} which allowed them to be promoted to the first division where they have remained since. In summer 2010, VCP Chinandega was not allowed to continue in the Premier Division after failing to pay the registration fee,[http://www.elnuevodiario.com.ni/deportes/79595 Deja fuera al VCP y “favorece” al América Fenifut arbitraria] – El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} which brought an end to the club's existence. ==List of Coaches== * {{flagicon|NCA}} Eduardo Vidal Alonso Gomez (2006–08) * {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Flavio Da Silva]] (2008 – March 2009) * {{flagicon|NCA}} Eduardo Vidal Alonso Gomez (April 2009 – January 2010) * {{flagicon|NCA}} Omar Zambrana (2010) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Primera División de Nicaragua}} [[Category:Defunct football clubs in Nicaragua]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Nicaragua]] {{Nicaragua-footyclub-stub}}
